document_title: Anxiety disorders: Causes, diagnosis and treatment methods
subsection_content:
A psychologist or psychiatrist will take a number of steps to help diagnose an anxiety disorder. First, they will ask detailed questions about your symptoms and medical history. Psychologists and psychiatrists will learn about the patient's symptoms and life through clinical conversations.(2)
To diagnose an anxiety disorder, criteria are outlined in the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM). This guide is published by the American Psychiatric Association and is used by mental health professionals. The following criteria must be met for an anxiety disorder diagnosis:
Excessive worry and anxiety about certain events or activities most days of the week for at least six months; Difficulty controlling anxious emotions; Anxiety or worry is a cause of significant stress or interferes with daily life.; Anxiety not related to a mental health condition, such as panic attacks, substance abuse or post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD).; At least three of the following symptoms in adults and one of the following in children: restlessness, fatigue, difficulty concentrating, irritability, tense muscles, or trouble sleeping.
Generalized anxiety disorder can be accompanied by other mental health problems, which can make diagnosis and treatment more complicated. Some disorders that often accompany generalized anxiety disorder include:
Panic disorder; Depression; Drug abuse; Post-traumatic stress disorder
Diagnosing an anxiety disorder will have many steps, done with experts and psychologists.
